anchor.surface_text: the principal point which has been argued before us on their behalf by Mr. Tatachari is that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that in a case where both the transferor and the transferee were equal in fraud and where the fraud contemplated has been carried out it is not open to the appellants to plead that fraud in defence against the claim made by respondent 1 to obtain possession of the properties conveyed to him benami by the Official Receiver Mr. Tatachari contends that where the parties are equally guilty estoppel cannot be pleaded against the appellants and the estate must be allowed to remain where it rests.

issues.text: That is the question which falls to be decided in the present appeal

anchor.surface_text: The High Court his upheld the plea of respondent 1 and has not allowed either respondent for the appellants to plead the fraud in support of their defence. Is this decision right? That is the question which falls to be decided in the present appeal. Reported decisions bearing on this question show that consideration of this problem often gives rise to what may be described as a battle of legal maxims.

issues.text: in deciding the point raised by the appellants we must look to the provisions of s. 84 of the Indian Trusts Act and nothing else

anchor.surface_text: It is then contended that in deciding the point raised by the appellants we must look to the provisions of s. 84 of the Indian Trusts Act and nothing else. The Indian Trusts Act is a comprehensive code and it is only in cases falling under s. 84 that it would be permissible to the Court to apply the equitable principles or to invoke considerations of public policy as the appellants purport to do.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the High Court was in error in number giving effect to the finding recorded by the trial companyrt that the fraud mutually agreed upon and companytemplated by respondents 1 and 2

holdings.text: the paramount consideration of public interest requires that the plea of fraud should be allowed to be raised and tried, and if it is upheld the estate should be allowed to remain where it rests. The adoption of this course, we think, is less injurious to public interest than the alternative course of giving effect to a fraudulent transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are inclined to hold that the paramount consideration of public interest requires that the plea of fraud should be allowed to be raised and tried, and if it is upheld the estate should be allowed to remain where it rests. The adoption of this course, we think, is less injurious to public interest than the alternative course of giving effect to a fraudulent transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Between two confederates in accomplished fraud, court should not actively assist plaintiff to obtain possession via decree (instrument of further fraud); instead passively allow possession to rest where it lies as less injurious to public interest.

holdings.text: There can be no question of estoppel in such a case for the obvious reason that the fraud in question was agreed by both the parties and both parties have assisted each other in carrying out the fraud.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no question of estoppel in such a case for the obvious reason that the fraud in question was agreed by both the parties and both parties have assisted each other in carrying out the fraud. When it is said that a person cannot plead his own fraud it really means that a person cannot be permitted to go to a Court of Law to seek for its assistance and yet base his claim for the Courts assistance on the ground of his fraud.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estoppel does not arise between equal participants who mutually agreed to and executed the fraud; nemo allegans applies to plaintiffs seeking affirmative relief based on own fraud, not pure defense.

holdings.text: We do not see how this section [s.84 Indian Trusts Act] is material or can give any assistance in the decision of the point before us... Since the present case is entirely outside s. 84 it inevitably falls to be considered on considerations of general policy.

anchor.surface_text: It is then contended that in deciding the point raised by the appellants we must look to the provisions of s. 84 of the Indian Trusts Act and nothing else. The Indian Trusts Act is a comprehensive code and it is only in cases falling under s. 84 that it would be permissible to the Court to apply the equitable principles or to invoke considerations of public policy as the appellants purport to do. Section 84 provides that where the owner of property transfers it to another for an illegal purpose and such purpose is not carried into execution, or the transferor is not as guilty as the transferee, or the effect of permitting the transferee to retain the property might be to defeat the provisions of any law, the transferee must hold the property for the benefit of the transferor. We do not see how this section is material or can give any assistance in the decision of the point before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case does not fit s.84 categories (transferee not in possession, fraud executed, equal guilt); Trusts Act not exhaustive code excluding general public policy considerations.

holdings.text: Even if respondent 1 has based his case on a conveyance the position still remains that as a result of the facts proved by respondent 2 and the appellants the conveyance is void ab initio. It is a document fraudulently executed and as such it conveys no title to the transferee at all.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it was urged that the principles on which the appellants rely are applicable to contracts and not to conveyances. A conveyance, it is argued, rests on a different basis from a contract, and so the English decisions cannot be pressed into service by the appellants. We are not impressed by this argument. Even if respondent 1 has based his case on a conveyance the position still remains that as a result of the facts proved by respondent 2 and the appellants the conveyance is void ab initio. It is a document fraudulently executed and as such it conveys no title to the transferee at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fraudulent execution renders conveyance void ab initio regardless of contract/conveyance distinction; no title passes where purpose is fraud on creditors and executed without consideration.

holdings.text: Therefore, we must hold that the High Court was in error in not giving effect to the finding recorded by the trial court that the fraud mutually agreed upon and contemplated by respondents 1 and 2 had been effectively carried out and that in the carrying out of the fraud both the parties were equally guilty. The appeal must, therefore, be allowed and the suit instituted by respondent 1 must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the High Court was in error in not giving effect to the finding recorded by the trial court that the fraud mutually agreed upon and contemplated by respondents 1 and 2 had been effectively carried out and that in the carrying out of the fraud both the parties were equally guilty. The appeal must, therefore, be allowed and the suit instituted by respondent 1 must be dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying above principles to facts (admitted fraud, equal guilt, possession with defendants), High Court erred in estopping defense; suit claim fails for lack of title.

holdings.text: the consensus of judicial opinion with the exception of the Madras High Court is in favour of the view which we have taken.

anchor.surface_text: This question has been the subject matter of judicial decisions in most of our High Courts and it appears that the consensus of judicial opinion with the exception of the Madras High Court is in favour of the view which we have taken. In Bombay the principle that in dealing with a contest between two participants in fraud possession should be allowed to remain where it rests appears to have been consistently accepted...

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are inclined to hold that the paramount consideration of public interest requires that the plea of fraud should be allowed to be raised and tried, and if it is upheld the estate should be allowed to remain where it rests. The adoption of this course, we think, is less injurious to public interest than the alternative course of giving effect to a fraudulent transfer.

edges.explanation: Holding h1 resolves the appeal's central question i5 by allowing the fraud plea on public interest grounds.

anchor.surface_text: There can be no question of estoppel in such a case for the obvious reason that the fraud in question was agreed by both the parties and both parties have assisted each other in carrying out the fraud. When it is said that a person cannot plead his own fraud it really means that a person cannot be permitted to go to a Court of Law to seek for its assistance and yet base his claim for the Courts assistance on the ground of his fraud.
The appeal must, therefore, be allowed and the suit instituted by respondent 1 must be dismissed.

It is then contended that in deciding the point raised by the appellants we must look to the provisions of s. 84 of the Indian Trusts Act and nothing else. The Indian Trusts Act is a comprehensive code and it is only in cases falling under s. 84 that it would be permissible to the Court to apply the equitable principles or to invoke considerations of public policy as the appellants purport to do. Section 84 provides that where the owner of property transfers it to another for an illegal purpose and such purpose is not carried into execution, or the transferor is not as guilty as the transferee, or the effect of permitting the transferee to retain the property might be to defeat the provisions of any law, the transferee must hold the property for the benefit of the transferor. We do not see how this section is material or can give any assistance in the decision of the point before us.
The appeal must, therefore, be allowed and the suit instituted by respondent 1 must be dismissed.

edges.explanation: h4 deems conveyance void based on proved benami facts, supporting benami

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it was urged that the principles on which the appellants rely are applicable to contracts and not to conveyances. A conveyance, it is argued, rests on a different basis from a contract, and so the English decisions cannot be pressed into service by the appellants. We are not impressed by this argument. Even if respondent 1 has based his case on a conveyance the position still remains that as a result of the facts proved by respondent 2 and the appellants the conveyance is void ab initio. It is a document fraudulently executed and as such it conveys no title to the transferee at all.
The appeal must, therefore, be allowed and the suit instituted by respondent 1 must be dismissed.
The appeal must, therefore, be allowed and the suit instituted by respondent 1 must be dismissed.
